explanation: The radioactive decay law describes the exponential decrease of unstable nuclei over time. The number of undecayed nuclei decreases exponentially with a characteristic decay constant λ. The half-life represents the time for half the nuclei to decay, independent of the initial amount.

definitions.definition: Number of undecayed nuclei at time t.
Initial number of nuclei at t = 0.
Decay constant (probability of decay per unit time).

assumptions: The decay probability per unit time is constant for each nucleus.
Decay events are independent and random.
Each nucleus has the same probability λdt of decaying in time interval dt.
The large number limit applies (statistical behavior).

derivation.description: The rate of decay is proportional to the number of undecayed nuclei present.
Separate variables to integrate the differential equation.
Integrate both sides from initial conditions to time t.
Apply properties of logarithms to simplify the integral.
Exponentiate both sides to get the exponential decay law.
Define half-life as the time when N(t) = N₀/2.
Simplify the exponential equation for half-life.
Take the natural logarithm to solve for half-life.
